Ten years after the @Lilly_Ledbetter Fair Pay Act was signed into law by President Obama, I proudly cosponsored the #PaycheckFairness Act to strengthen our laws & bring us one step closer to finally closing the gender wage gap. #Ledbetter10

We can’t let this disparity, which is worse for women of color, continue to exist. The #PaycheckFairness Act would make necessary fixes to narrow the wage gap and ensure that American women earn a fair wage to support their families.

Equal pay for equal work means giving women the opportunity to achieve economic security and the ability to provide for their families. But in America, women still earn on average only about 80 percent of what men earn.

The ball is firmly in @senatemajldr’s court. But rather than taking up the House-passed legislation, he is watching from the sidelines as this shutdown continues. He’s holding up the legislative process to satisfy the President’s whims.

The House has already passed bipartisan legislation – H.R. 21 and House Joint Resolution 1 – to end this shutdown, reopen shuttered agencies and fund the Department of Homeland Security through February 8th. @senatemajldr has the power to bring that legislation up for a vote.

Federal workers aren’t leverage. They’re the men and women who serve our communities and provide vital services to Americans. They aren’t enjoying a paid vacation, as one White House adviser callously put it. They’re paying the price for the President’s govern-by-chaos approach.

Yesterday, I met with federal workers in Northern Nevada who are struggling to support their families. They’ve made it clear that we need to end this senseless shutdown. Let’s show them the respect and dignity they deserve.

We should not be abdicating to the Executive Branch. We should be doing our job.
 
Let’s open this government. Let’s show these federal workers that they aren’t political pawns.

We know we can pass legislation to open the government. We did it in the last Congress. It’s the president’s decision whether to accept/veto. If he decides to veto it, we should override. The founders and framers set up a process so that no one branch of government has control.

The shutdown is threatening wildlife and public safety because staff are furloughed and federal contractors aren’t getting paid. Important projects are delayed and services Nevadans rely on have been halted.

This is only one of the major impacts on Nevadans. It’s not the only major disruption we’re seeing. I spoke today with Nevadans who work at the BLM, U.S. Fish and Wildlife, U.S. Geological Survey and USDA Rural Development.

A single mom told me that she recently moved to Nevada after getting her dream job. She used her savings to move and buy a house. Without the certainty of a paycheck, she asked me, “how do I pay the bills, support my mother and my 8-year-old?”

I spoke with parents who both work for the federal government and are not receiving any income. They have four children. Given the uncertainty of when the government will re-open, they have no idea how they could support their family without any pay.

The consensus I heard from federal workers is simple: re-open the government. Thousands of Nevada’s federal workers are worried about paying the bills, supporting their children and keeping up with their mortgage payments.
This morning, I’m going to hear from Nevadans whose families and finances are being thrown into chaos because of President Trump’s senseless shutdown. Follow along this thread for updates.

In 2018, Nevada received over $300M in federal grants, which went toward early education programs, rural water infrastructure, broadband internet in our rural communities, zero-emission buses, health care, and numerous other projects benefitting Nevadans all across the state.

Federal dollars can make the difference in filling a gap in an organization’s budget, or in helping critical community organizations increase capacity to serve more people. It was an honor to speak today at the Inaugural Silver State Grants Conference. pic.twitter.com/wX2GkK7xi8

The solution is simple: reopen the government. Stop holding federal workers hostage for political gain. They are not political pawns. They are not leverage. Let’s show federal workers the respect and dignity they deserve.

They signed up to serve the American people. They deserve the certainty of a functioning gov't and a steady paycheck. These are people who do an honest day’s work and expect a steady paycheck and a gov't led by a president who cares about their needs and their family’s safety.

I’ve heard from many federal workers in Nevada. They didn’t “sign up” to live in constant fear that their paychecks may be withheld for political gain; to wonder if they will be able to pay their rent on time, cover childcare costs or put food on the table for their families.

Our President’s govern-by-chaos approach has pulled the rug from under hundreds of thousands of federal workers and contractors across the country who are currently furloughed or being forced to work without pay, including over 3,000 in Nevada.
I’m heading to the Senate floor to call on @realDonaldTrump to reopen the government. You can watch it live on Facebook:  http://facebook.com/SenatorCortezMasto/ …

It’s important to ensure Nevada communities are prepared for the impact of severe weather.  My provision to help preserve $181M in federal funding for critical flood control projects in the Truckee Meadows was included in America’s Water Infrastructure Act of 2018.
